text: The sun isn’t even up yet, but a sea of Amazonian red ros shine under the lights of the downtown flower mart. More than 80 VENDORS begin their day, readying their stal at the downtown flower mart where Angelenos come to buy t freshest, most extravagant flora in town. It's always springtime here. INT. REED BENNETT’S HOUSE - MID-WILSHIRE - 5 A.M. REED BENNETT (late 20s) wakes up easily, naturally. Handsome, rugged. Smile on his face, happy to be alive. H looks at the clock beside him. 5 a.m. Softly, he turns hi head. MORLEY CLARKSON (late 20s), lays sound asleep besid him. Reed gets up. Pulls on pajama bottoms. Then reaches under the bed, and pulls out a small box. Opens it. The perfect engagement ring inside. He sits on the bed, looking at her sleeping face. Softly pulls her left hand out from under the pillow. Reed now holds her naked left hand. When Morley wakes up. Catches the scene. She starts to say something, but:
I know you don’t like a big, mushy, romantic scene. No skywriting. No writing your name in flower petals. She laughs.

Just you and me. Together. And frankly, that’s all I want. That’s all I need. I love you Morley. Will you marry me? He looks at her, expectantly. And breathes a sigh of reli as she SMILES. EXT. REED BENNETT’S HOUSE - 5:40 A.M. Reed, now wearing a dark blue mechanics style jacket with words “Rita Flora” on the back, athletically barrels down stairs. Energy high. Excitement on his face. He gets inside a DELIVERY VAN.  2/18/9 2.
Reed hops into the passenger side. ALPHONSO, 40s and from Salvador, is at the wheel. He looks at Reed, studying him
She said no. I knew it.
You did?
I just mean -
She said yes.
That’s great!
Why would she say no?
I don’t know why I said that. I prepare for the worst. Part of the immigrant mentality. But - she said yes! Reed regains his enthusiasm.

She said yes. She said YES. I’m still trying to process. Morley is actually going to marry me. I’m getting married. And today I can be the kind of cheeseball who tells random people at the ATM about it because it’s Valentine’s Day and people are all about love today. Alphonso pulls the VAN away, NEARLY HITTING A PASSING CAR

The set of the KTLA news is a flurry activity as the morn show is about to go on the air.  2/18/9 3. KELVIN, late 30s, African-American, walks briskly through set, holding a piece of paper. He spots SUSAN, 50s, across the stage, and makes a bee-li for her. As he approaches, he holds up the paper. He’s clearly annoyed.
What the hell is this? Susan half-smiles, seeming to enjoy his frustration.
That’s your assignment, Kelvin.
My assignment? Since when do I get assignments?
Since there’s nothing else going on. Susan turns and walks through the stage, Kelvin follows.
I’m the sports anchor, Susan. There’s always something going on.
The Super Bowl was last week. There are only two NBA games tonight. No one gives a crap about hockey. Like I said, there’s nothing going on.
Actually I was working on something big - Susan stops, getting a little annoyed.

What were you working on Kelvin? Was another one of the Cincinnati Bengals arrested? You got a tip on another referee fixing basketball games? Oooh - maybe you’ve got an exclusive one on one with Michael Vick’s dog trainer?
It’s Valentine’s Day. All I want is your basic man on the street remote about what this day means to people. I want happy. I want romance. I want love.

And you should have that. But, seriously Susan - I’m not the right guy. I hate Valentine’s Day. Least favorite holiday. It’s not even a holiday, really, we don’t get the day off. So we have to go to work AND buy shit for people we might not even know in two weeks? No thanks. Susan laughs -
Come on -

I’m serious. It’s the single man’s worst nightmare. I shut down dating from New Years Eve til Presidents Day just to avoid the whole thing. Saves me a lot of cash and heartache. Susan looks at him, almost sympathetically.

Well, be that as it may - you’re a professional. I know you don’t like soccer but you give those Galaxy scores with a smile on your face. You'll do fine. She turns and leaves him standing there. EXT. FLOWER MART - DOWNTOWN L.A. - 6:00 A.M. Open for business and already crowded with wholesale BUYE readying for the busiest day of the year. Rows and rows of commercial floral delivery vans. Alphonso parks the van. Reed hops out. Behind him, two mo delivery vans bearing the RITA FLORA name park beside him Two LATINO DRIVERS stand outside, waiting for him.  2/18/9 5.

You three pick up all the roses from Sam and load them in the trucks. I have to find something for Morley. Something spectacular. INT. AIRPLANE - 6:00 A.M. Jumbo jet. Long, overnight flight. All the passengers are asleep, fervently lost in their individual dreams. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT rubs her sleepy eyes. Gets up. She pins a heart on her lapel: Happy Valentine’s Day. Smacks it and it blinks red. She begins her hourly rounds Couple after couple asleep. Until she stops at one. A whi woman, KATE, (30s), in a military uniform, has fallen asl on the shoulder of HOLDEN, (30s) an African-American man. He leans into her, comforted by her warmth. The Flight Attendant pulls up the single blanket, wrappin them both tighter into a cocoon. EXT. FLOWER MART - VENDOR - 6:30 A.M. As Reed walks the aisles empty-handed, he’s jostled by al the other buyers, loaded down with fresh flowers. Unperturbed by the rudeness, Reed keeps smiling, wishing the Vendors, by name, a good morning. Finally, Reed finds a heavyset Italian ex-New Yorker with coffee spilled down his shirt, GUISEPPE (50s). Reed walks right behind the counter and smacks a kiss on Guiseppe’s cheek.
Guiseppe. I need you.

Great. But could you stand camera right? You're blocking my good angle. Guiseppe points to a three-man CAMERA CREW shooting close of all the flowers. KELVIN, now wearing a suit, on-air ma up, is quite debonair.
Morley said yes so I’m gonna need something --  2/18/9 6. Guiseppe looks at him.
She said yes?
Yes. What is the deal with you guys? She wants to marry me - I swear. Guiseppe hugs him.
That’s great news.
But I can’t just give her roses today. I need to find something amazing.
I think I have the perfect thing.
Yeah?
It’s in back.
Guiseppe - followed by Reed - goes deep into the refrigerator. Pulls out something in a LONG, BLACK CLOSED BOX.
What’s in it? He starts to open it. But Guiseppe stops him with a loud gruff.
No! Don’t open it until it’s just the right time.
The right time?
Just trust me, Reed. I had this handpicked and flown over from Thailand, just in case you needed magic.  2/18/9
Really?
Well, also, Damon Wayans shops here and I thought he might like it - but you got here first. Reed delicately takes the box.
Thank you, Guiseppe. You're the best.
Reed, with the black box, and Guiseppe return. Kelvin approaches, smiles politely at Reed, then says to Guisepp
Sir? If we can just get a few words from you on camera, then we'll be done. Kelvin turns to the camera crew. They start rolling.

(into mic) We're here at the downtown Flower Mart in Los Angeles with wholesale dealer Guiseppe Carletti, where Valentine’s Day starts at three a.m. Guiseppe, on average, how Many red roses are sold on Valentine’s Day? Guiseppe is staring into the camera. Reed nudges him.
The Captain and Tennille were married on Valentine’s Day. Used to non-sequitur camera shock, Kelvin tries again.
Approximately 110 million red roses are sold in America on Valentine’s Day, am I right?
So were Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid, but that didn’t end so well. Never understood why. She’s hot, that Meg Ryan. (MORE )
GUISEPPE (cont'd) I wouldn't mind delivering her flowers, if-you-know-what-I-mean. Guiseppe nods suggestively to camera. Reed steps in, protective.
110 million. That’s correct, Kelvin. And California produces about sixty percent of them.
And your name, sir? Reed smiles easily into the camera.
Reed Bennett. Owner of Rita Flora on La Brea and Sixth.
Ah, as a florist, you must hear quite a few stories on Valentine’s Day. Do you believe in love?
Hell, yes. Love is still the most shocking act left on the planet. Reed smiles. Electric. Kelvin knows a sound bite when he hears it. Smiles in the camera:
Back to you, Cynthia. Signals the end. The camera turns off.
Thank you.
Of course. You're welcome. Follow Kelvin as he moves off with his crew:
That’s a start. Now, where else do they keep the deluded people? The guys walk off. Guiseppe and Reed watch them go. Guiseppe, baffled, turns Reed:  2/18/9 9.
Did I just tell the news that I wanted to give it to Meg Ryan?

On JULIA PERSINGER (late 20s), beautiful, quirky, sitting in bed, smiling as she watches: DR. HARRISON COPELAND (40s, distinguished), a Reproductiv Endocrinologist (fertility expert) put on his tie. The TV SET is on in the background. Beat, as Harrison turns and takes her in. He clearly love her. She catches him looking at her, smiles.
Don’t leave today.
I told you yesterday, I have to fly up to San Francisco.
But it’s Valentine’s Day.

I know. And your face was the first thing I wanted to see this morning. But I have two in vitros at the clinic today. You can’t tell follicles when to burst. She moves around the condo now. Blacks and greys. Very male. As Julia reaches for her clothes, sexy red lingerie HARRISON (CONT’D) What about you? Are you really going to that dinner tonight?
I don’t know. It technically is only for single people. But since you’re gonna be gone I’ve got nothing else to do. And it’s really important to Kara. It’sa tradition.

You don’t really hate Valentine's Day, do you?  2/18/9 10. Julia is now a whirl, getting dressed. Shoes flying, skir pulled on. Tugging a brush through her hair. Trying to catch up and get ready to leave when he leaves.

A recently divorced, handsome doctor such as yourself doesn’t know what it’s like to be single. But for us unhitched gals, well, it sucks. It’s like some sort of cosmic bitch-slap for singlefolk. The Universe saying, “Hey you! Remember what it felt like when you still had braces and cystic acne and no one wanted to ask you to winter formal? Well, nothing’s changed!” Harrison smiles.
I would take you to winter formal. And I definitely would have prescribed you some Retin A for the skin. She smiles back at him, but her attention is pulled to th screen.
..-Love is still the most shocking act left on the planet. Julia smiles big.
...Thank you, Reed Bennett of Rita Flora.
I love that place. They have the most beautiful flowers. Harrison takes this in. Smiles at the joy on her face.
THREE HIGH SCHOOL GIRLS, all wearing the standard Marlbor uniform, burst out of Starbucks on Larchmont, full of adolescent energy. They sip their chai lattes as they amb down the street.
Flowers make me sad.  2/18/9 11.
I know. They die.
Right? What kind of gift is that?
One that’s trying to send a message. Everything dies. Get used to it. As the girls continue to talk, we close in on JANICE (18) lags behind them, looking at her PHONE.
She has ONE NEW TEXT. From someone named ALEX. It reads: “TODAY IS THE DAY!" She SMILES, somewhat shyly, as she reads this, then begin type her response.

The Loyola High School boys lacrosse practice is winding down. ALEX, 18, still in uniform, with helmet off, stands the sideline watching the second string run some drills. His PHONE, which sits in his helmet on the ground, BUZZES He picks it up, reads the return text from JANICE:
“YES! ye He smiles in anticipation.
A 1940s four-plex on Spaulding. The typical just-moved-to L.A.-in-your-20s crash pad.

These apartments all have the same floor plan - all of th rooms off of a long, narrow hallway. In one of the bedroo we find JASON and LIZ (both mid 20s) curled up under a sh The decor says 25 year old messy guy.
Hello. Liz smiles shyly at him.  2/18/9 12.
Hi.
I’m used to seeing you every morning -- but not exactly like this. She laughs.
Would you prefer I were naked and wrapped in a sheet when you drop packages at my desk?
As a matter of fact, I would. I don’t think that would be breaking any kind of office regulations. He puts his arms around her, and they start to kiss passionately.
This, however, might start to draw attention... Jason laughs.
How is it possible that we didn’t start hanging out until three weeks ago?
I don’t know. Maybe you were scoping out some of the other assistants...
I don’t think so. They kiss again. They are all smiles, as Liz glances at t clock.
So, I guess I better get going soon...
Uh, OK. Great. She hesitates for a moment, waiting for something.  2/18/9 13.

Well... OK... I guess I’1l just see you there... She hesitates again, looking at Jason. He looks back at h Again - she’s waiting for something. He’s clearly not sur what. And whatever it is doesn’t come. She finally gets u

Liz drives a little Hyundai - pulls up to a stoplight on Beverly Blvd. Liz looks out the window - and sees Jason, on his Vespa, waving to her. She gives him a thin lipped smile. He motions for her to roll down her window. She does.
Hi.
Hi. Jason smiles again at Liz. She forces a smile back. It’s awkward as they wait for the light. It FINALLY turns gree

Bye! They mercifully pull away. EXT. EDGAR & ESTELLE’S HOUSE - BACK YARD - MORNING French doors open into the backyard. ESTELLE (70s), her flaxen white hair, pale skin and full lips telling the st of a once great beauty, is still sleeping in the bed. EDGAR (70s), a tall old-fashioned gentleman in a sweater arm patches, walks slowly through the overgrown English garden, cutting flowers with a pair of garden shears. INT. EDGAR & ESTELLE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - MORNING Edgar places the flowers, now in a drinking glass, with a of Chanel No. 5 perfume on the nightstand beside his slee wife. He kisses her on the forehead, waking her gently. She sti smiles at the man she’s been married to for 51 years. See the flowers and perfume.  2/18/9 14.
Edgar, we said we weren't going to celebrate Valentine’s Day anymore.
I lied. Estelle reaches under her pillow. Pulls out a brand new pipe, wrapped in a red ribbon. Hands it to him.
So did I.

EDISON (10) sits at the kitchen table. A multi-pack of ki mini-boxes of cereal sits in front of him next to an empt cereal bowl. The kitchen TV is on in the background. Edison takes his eyes off the TV and looks down at the store-bought box of VALENTINES laid out in front of him. He finds the biggest He signs it, “I love you. Edison.” On the outside, he dra a simple heart and sets it apart from the others.

Edgar and Estelle walk, both dressed now. She in her lipstick. He with slicked hair. Both adhering to the old ways of being “dressed” for the breakfast table. She lean into him. He links her arm into his. They stop in the doorway, watching Edison write out his Valentines. A sadness passes over Estelle.
The boy misses his mother. Every year, she was his Valentine. Edgar looks at her, sympathetic.
We're doing the best we can. Together, they enter the kitchen. Loving smiles now.
Where Edison refers to his class list and starts addressi the rest when Edgar and Estelle walk in. They both kiss their grandson, when Estelle notices the empty cereal bow  2/18/9 15.
What about your breakfast, Edison?
Not hungry. I’m in love.

Running down the beach fluidly is SEAN JACKSON, 35, clear an athlete who’s stride leaves not an ounce of wasted mot He approaches a massive HOUSE right on the beach, runs up deck stairs and into the house.

Sean, just out of the shower, enters the impressive bathr in a towel. He grabs his toothbrush, begins to brush his teeth. Looks to his right at the other sink of the two si vanity. It’s devoid of any personal items except for ONE TOOTHBRUSH sitting in a cup. Sean stares at it. Finally he grabs the lone toothbrush a tosses it into the trash can at his feet. Continues brush his teeth.

Sean, now dressed, enters from the kitchen holding a prot type shake. The TV is tuned to ESPN - the morning edition Sportscenter. ON THE TV - The ANCHOR sits at the familiar Sportscenter desk, with a graphic of SEAN OVER HIS RIGHT SHOULDER.

With the NFL season officially over, the only lingering question is - what will Sean Jackson do? IN THE HOUSE - This clearly gets Sean’s attention. He sit on his couch, watches. ON THE TV - The anchor continues: ANCHOR (CONT’D) A devastating loss in the Super Bowl last week leaves his future with the Chargers in question. Over FOOTAGE OF SEAN, AT QB, VARIOUS HIGHLIGHT PLAYS.  2/18/9 16. ANCHOR (V.O.) (CONT’D) His contract is up, and at 35, he’s not getting any younger. Do the Chargers want him back? If not, will he test the waters of free agency? Or will he make this easier on everyone and just retire? IN THE HOUSE - As Sean watches, that last line hits him h
We expect an answer to all these questions and more over the next few days... Sean flips the TV off, not happy. He picks up the PHONE, dials.

A spare modern home up Outpost. From overhead we find KAR 37, sleeping alone in perhaps the largest bed available f purchase. She looks like a 2 year old on a normal size be The PHONE RINGS, startling her awake. She crawls across t bed to her nightstand and hits the SPEAKER BUTTON ON HER PHONE.
Hello?
Kara - it’s Sean.
Hey. What’s going on? Kara sits up. She leans over and grabs her LAPTOP from th nightstand, opens it up.
Sean now stands on his deck overlooking the ocean.
Can’t you stop these assholes on ESPN from talking shit about me?
Um, no, not really. I'ma publicist Sean, not a dictator. Sean’s pacing his deck, thinking. Kara types away on her laptop.  2/18/9 17.
OK. Then I need to make a decision. I can’t take this anymore. Are you free today?
Yeah, pretty much. Kara keeps typing, half-engaged in the conversation.
I can hear you typing. Are you checking your email while we're talking?
No. I’m checking my Evite. Sean actually cracks a smile.
Oh right. Your “I Hate Valentine’s Day Dinner”. You still do that?
It’s a tradition. Me and all my friends get together and share our mutual disdain for the holiday. It’s fun.
It sounds fun.
No it doesn’t.
It sounds like a nightmare. Kara laughs.
Expecting a big turnout?

I‘11 tell you in a second. Kara punches in the Evite address. The site comes up. ON THE SCREEN - We see Kara’s nicely designed Evite - the title “I HATE VALENTINE’S DAY DINNER” scrolling across th top.  2/18/9 18. We move to the NUMBER OF ATTENDEES LINE. The number following it - 0. WITH KARA - As she squints her eyes, not sure she’s readi it right. She stares in shocked silence.
So?
I gotta call you back. Kara, slams her computer shut, hits the speaker button on nightstand again, hops out of bed quickly. She grabs her CELL PHONE out of her purse, dials.

La Brea Avenue. Reed has turned a typical floral shop int hip coffee spot, selling muffins and coffee to go. Fresh flowers on every bistro table. The place is PACKED. Long lines of CUSTOMERS buying flowers from an already ti STAFF. Reed is deftly managing the lines at the very busy coffee counter. He hands coffee and muffins to A COUPLE.
Here you go. I gave you two banana nut for the price of one -- little engagement special. They couple SMILES as they take their goods.

Who’s up next? In honor of Valentine’s day - and my engagement - a good proposal story means a free specialty drink. He is obviously skilled at entertaining the crowd. As he goes to steam another latte - MORLEY walks in. As soon as the staff-members see her -- they BURST INTO APPLAUSE. Re turns to see her and joins in the cheering.
The future Mrs. Bennett, ladies and gentlemen.
We're so happy for you two!! As they clap and congratulate her, she smiles very uncomfortably.  2/18/9 She looks He kisses 19.
I wasn’t really expecting this... pleadingly at Reed.
Morley really does not like people making a fuss over her - her -
So I just thought we'd carry her on our shoulders around the store like one time - two times tops - They laugh.
I'm kidding. (handing his apron to a clerk) Can you take over for me for a minute? He ushers Morley into the back.
Nice to see you. Fiance. That word is weird, right? Have you said it yet?
Not yet.
So, did you just come by to bask in the glow of our fiance-ness? Try saying it once-- She reaches into her purse -
You actually just left your cell phone charging on the kitchen counter - so I thought I’d drop it off. She goes to hand him the phone with her LEFT HAND.
That was sweet. Thanks.  2/18/9 20.
Of course. I know you need it when you're making deliveries. Redd looks at her hand. NO RING. She looks up - sees the hurt in this face.
Don’t be upset. It’s a beautiful ring. Beautiful. It’s just - so big. And sparkly.
That’s bad?
It’s just - a lot. I mean for work and stuff.
Yeah?

You know how women get - they see the ring - and then next thing you know you’re giving the whole engagement story to a complete stranger. Who wants that? Morley looks up at Reed - who is suppressing a smile.
I don’t know - that sounds kind of nice. Maybe I should wear the ring? She LAUGHS.
I’ve always wondered why men don’t have to wear engagement rings. They’re engaged, too.
Good point. I feel slighted.
You are welcome to try mine. If you can pull of an emerald cut diamond with pave band - you are more of a man than I even thought. He laughs, and kisses her.  2/18/9 21.
Well, I should let you get back to the masses out there. Morley turns to go, and is wrapped into a BEAR HUG by Alphonso.
Congratulations.
Thank you. He kisses her on the cheek.
Oh. Thanks. And on the other cheek.
Okay. I should probably get going.
I am so happy for you guys. She smiles as he pulls away. Reed laughs.
See you at home. Fiance. She takes off.
Kate wakes up, startled to find herself wrapped in someon else’s arms. She jerks up, immediately alert and containe
Excuse me, sir. Holden’s awake, and has been for over an hour.
It’s just a shoulder. Ona fourteen-hour flight, it’s the least I could do.
You should have moved me. I apologize for the inconvenience. Kate adjusts her uniform, puts herself back together.  2/18/9 22.
Are you on active duty?
Yes, sir.
Loved one in Los Angeles? Kate doesn’t answer. Doesn’t like the personal questions.
I’m sure he’1ll be happy to see you.
I hope so. I’ve been on duty for two years now. Holden smiles.
Will you be staying long?
I only have 24 hours leave in Los Angeles.
Ah, so you’re a romantic.
Excuse me?
Fourteen hours to and from Iraq for one night with your husband? I'd call that romantic. She doesn’t know how to take that. So she says nothing.

A two-bedroom Art Deco apartment on Sycamore, one block f La Brea. Warm, inviting. Julia, just out of the shower, walks through her living r in a towel. She grabs her phone, sees she has a message. She puts it on speaker:
Hey, Julia, it’s Kara. So, I’m freaking out a bit. I’m really hoping you're coming to my dinner tonight. (MORE )
KARA (ON SPEAKER) (cont'd) It’s turning out to be a little - smaller - than I had hoped. OK. Call me. Julia deletes the message. She thinks about it, picks up phone and dials.
(into phone) Harrison? Where are you?
From inside his convertible Porsche, Harrison answers.
(into phone) I can’t talk now, honey. I’m about to pull into LAX. I’11 call you when I land. He hangs up. Then pulls up to the MALIBU COLONY GATES. Hi face pained at the lie.
Harrison walks in, carrying his daughter OLIVIA (10) on h shoulders, to find ALEXANDRA (40s), pouring orange juice.
Daddy was up all night delivering TWINS! Two babies from the same mommy . He puts Olivia down, walks over to his wife. Kisses her.
Sorry it took so long. We didn’t deliver until almost four, so I slept at the condo. She smiles, used to it.
How'd the delivery go?
Good. All things considered. Olivia picks up a LARGE VALENTINE. Hands it to him.

This is for you.  2/18/9 24. He opens it. The childish pencil writing of, “I love you. Olivia.” He looks at her, looks at his wife. Then suddenl breaks. A few tears. No warning. Then he shrugs it off.
Don’t you like it, Daddy?
Of course I do. Daddy’s just tired, that’s all. He walks over to Alexandra. Kisses her deeply.
What was that for?
Nothing. I’11l see you tonight.

(as he works) All day. Names on shoulders, hearts on ass cracks.

Busiest day of the year. And it’s the gift that keeps on giving.

Because I take off more names than I put on. You know why? Because--- He stops his work, points to tattoo on his arm: LOVE IS PISS.
That used to say Lucille. Kelvin looks at his CREW. Makes the “cut” sign.  2/18/9 25.
Julia enters Rita Flora, smiles when she sees Reed behind counter. She sidles up to him.

I saw you on TV this morning. “Love is the most shocking act left on the planet.” That should be on a bumper sticker. But she smiles, teasing. He goes to the espresso machine, starts making Julia’s coffee himself. He hands her the coffee. Refuses her money.
Happy Valentine’s Day.
Thank you - but don’t try to deflect. How did it go? Reed peeks up at the line - growing longer by the second. But can’t resist Julia’s expectant face. He turns to a
Henry, you got this? HENRY nods. Reed steps aside, to talk to Julia more privately. Before he can start, she looks at his face.
Oh, shit... Reed looks at her.
Does anyone have any confidence in me? She said yes. Julia smiles big and HUGS him.
Yay! That’s amazing. How much did she love that ring? He hedges. Not wanting to disappoint her.
She thought it was a beautiful ring, just not the right ring. Julia bites her lip, instantly sensitive for him.  2/18/9
It just wasn’t her speed. It’s fine.
I guess. But I feel like if Harrison and I ever got engaged or anything, I’d be happy with a cigar band. Reed looks a little taken aback.
Wow. Things are going well with him, then?
Yeah. He had to go to San Francisco today. I was thinking of surprising him. You know, fly up there and rock his world on the Golden Gate Bridge. Too much?
I don’t think so.
Really? So if a girl did that for you, you wouldn’t be freaked out?
No. I love spontaneity. Julia considers this, then smiles.
That’s true. I remember in college you made me drive around all night with you looking for the perfect donut. That was spontaneous.
And sickening. Humans are not meant to ingest that much fried dough.
No they’re not. Reed smiles. ALPHONSO interrupts them.
No mas raffia, boss.  2/18/9 27.
Take the flight, Julia. Valentine’s Day is like New Year's Eve. You don’t think, you just go for it. He smiles, and leaves her thinking.
In the bowels of the agency, Jason, and his buddy, DANNY, sort a gargantuan pile of mail. These aren't just any mailroom guys - these guys are good looking, dressed well, agents in the making.
She wouldn’t even give you a ride in to work?
No, she would. She just thinks it’s better to keep it discreet, you know?
So why are you telling me? He has a good point, but before Jason can respond, JED, a third mailroom guy enters, carrying TWO GIANT FLOWER ARRANGEMENTS.
Dude, I hate Valentine’s Day. Why can’t these pansy guys just go upstairs and deliver their flowers to their girlfriends themselves? Jason looks confused - and a little horrified.
Wait - what?
These guys just drop the stuff of at the curb - they don’t want to take the time to -
No - wait - it’s Valentine’s Day? But it’s Monday. I thought it was always on a Thursday.  2/18/9 28.
Dude, that’s Thanksgiving.
You're 25. You’ve thought that for 25 years? That’s really weird. Jason looks a little panicked.
Shit. I didn’t even say Happy Valentine’s Day. Danny and Jed start to laugh.
And you have nothing planned?
No. But we’ve only been together a couple of weeks. Maybe she doesn’t expect anything. Jed and Danny share a look.
You're screwed. Off Jason, not liking the sound of that.
